div.p: 2. V:45. Saturday.

Began reading Sir James Mackintosh’s History of the reign of James the second. My catarrhal cough and my lameness yet disable me, for all vigorous action— The deaf and dumb young man named W. S. Smith came for the third time, to me for employment which I am unable to find or to procure for him—

At the House, upon the call for Reports from standing and then from Select Committees, there were only two or three presented which occasioned no debate Mr Patton, Chairman of the Committee of the Territories moved to suspend the rules of private business for one hour to take up a Bill from the Senate for establishing the Territory of Wisconsin which was agreed to.— Committee of the whole on the Union, Speight in the Chair— The Bill was long, and Patton said the question of boundary would not be involved in it at all— But it bounded the new Territory, on the North-east corner of the State of Illinois May of that State moved to insert the words 42 degrees 30. minutes North Latitude—to which Patton, and Jones the delegate from the proposed territory acquiesced in; but which I opposed— I made a very few remarks, but found that I could use my voice so as to be heard— I saw my opposition would be useless; but the hour expired and the orders of the day, private business was called— Two successive Committees of the whole were raised, Ward first and then Fuller. Philo. C, in the Chair, andprivate Bills passed from Committee to the House and to a third reading— The House adjourned near four O’Clock and I went to see Mr Tippets improved Steam engine, which is never to explode, but it was out of order— In the Evening I went to the Capitol, and heard a Lecture two hours and a half long from Mr Reynolds in support of his old project of a scientific naval expedition to the South Pole and pacific Ocean— I came home between 10 and 11. Sick and wearied out.
3. V:30. Sunday.

At the Presbyterian Church heard a young man by the name of Grundy, a nephew of the Senator from Tennessee of that name, who was present. The text was John 3.3, “Jesus answered and said unto him, verily, verily, I say unto thee. Except a man be born again, he cannot see the kingdom of God.”— This text is the quintessence of Calvinism, but the discourse endeavoured to reconcile it with reason— The main inexplicable difficulty in my judgment is, how a strong metaphorical image addressed by Jesus to Nicodemus a Jew, can be applied to Christians born two thousand years afterwards— In the afternoon I attended with my wife at St. John’s Church where Mr Hawley read the Evening service for Easter Sunday, and preached from 2. Samuel 7.18. [“]Then went king David in, and sat before the Lord, and he said, Who am I, O Lord God? and what is my house, that thou hast brought me hitherto? 19. And this was yet a small thing in thy sight O Lord God: but thou hast spoken also of thy servants house for a great while to come. And is this the manner of man, O Lord God?”— This text seemed to have been selected to give notice that the Church stood in great need of repairs and that the pew holders would be shortly called upon to contribute for that purpose— Mr Hawley, in the midst of the service baptized three female children—
4. V:30. Monday.
A Polish exile

My lameness continues and increases— My foot was so much swollen this morning that I hesitated whether to attend the Meeting of the House, but concluded finally to go— Petition day; but Hawes had the floor upon the Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky relating to the public Lands, and though I requested him to yield it, for the reception of Petitions, he declined, and spoke till One O’Clock, against W. H. Harrison, and in favour of M. Van Buren as a candidate for the Presidency— He did not finish but upon the call of the special order of the day, Wise moved a suspension of the Rules to enable him to present a Resolution, for the appointment of a Select Committee, with power to send for persons and papers, to enquire into the selection and agency of the Deposit Banks, and the connection of Reuben M. Whitney with them and with the Government— But the Motion to suspend the Rules was rejected by yeas and nays 84 to 91— Balie Peyton, then moved to suspend the rules, to offer a Resolution to make the Bill for regulating the deposit Banks, should be made the special order of the day, from one O’Clock on the second Monday of May, and every succeeding day, until it shall be decided—this motion was also rejected by yeas and nays 67 to 99. Peyton said he should renew the motion at a suitable time—

The Navy Bill was then taken up, and Jarvis made a speech of about two hours in favour of the appropriation—after which the Committee rose, Robertson of Virginia having taken the floor, and the House adjourned— I took Jarvis home— And my lameness in the Evening was so painful, that I almost despaired of being able to attend the House to-morrow— My wife was also suddenly taken ill this evening.
5. V:30. Tuesday—

I could not, as I should have done, refrain from rising this morning, as soon as it was full day-light, and I read some pages in Sir James Mackintosh’s History of the reign of James the second— I called at Tippet’s shop, and inspected again his Steam engine, the operation of which was more successful, than when I had seen it last— At the house, before the Reports from Committees were called I obtained leave of the House to present the Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts relating to the North-Eastern boundary of the United States, which were read, ordered to be printed and laid on the table— I then presented the petition of William Patterson, for a Patent, for dying woollen without oak-bark— The petition was received and referred to the select Committee appointed upon another patent case— Among the Bills reported

was one reported by the Committee of Ways and Means was one limiting the operation of the first section of the New-York fire bill, to bonds given before the 17th. of December last. The bill itself applied to bonds given before the 19th of March when the bill passed— The Bill passed both Houses this day, I objected to its passing thus precipitately as in substance an ex post facto Law, but without effect, as that was precisely the necessity for its immediate passage— Wise repeated his motion to suspend the Rules to offer a Resolution of Enquiry, concerning the Deposit Banks—rejected by yeas and nays 89 to 91. Peyton attempted to repeat his resolution for fixing a time to consider the Bill for the regulation of the Deposit Banks; but the hour of one, and the special order of the day came up— The Navy-Appropriation Bill—on which Robertson made a Speech of 2 hours and a half, when the Committee rose, and I prevailed on the House to take up the Bills on their third reading, fifteen of which were passed, and the House adjourned shortly before 5. O’Clock— There was much dallying opposition to this effort for the transaction of business— I had a painful evening.
6. V:30. Wednesday—

The swelling and inflammation of my leg and foot, increasing from day to day makes it every day more doubtful, whether I shall be able to continue without interruption my attendance at the House— I hesitated much yesterday, and this morning still more— But I conclude to attend till it becomes impracticable— Mr James’s Son called and paid his mother’s rent— The ground was covered with snow this morning

At the House among the Reports of Committees was one from the Committee of Commerce, a joint Resolution suspending till the further order of Congress, a section of the general Appropriation Act of the first Session of the last Congress, prohibiting any increase of the number of custom-house Officers; Objections were made against it; but it was necessary to drive it through— Whittlesey objected to its being done in the form of a Resolution—and Sutherland moved amendment to turn it into a Bill which was agreed to—and he moved to limit his Bill to the end of the present Session of Congress also adopted, and the Bill was run through all its stages, and passed— Wise reproduced his resolution for an enquiry into the condition of the deposit banks, with a long preamble; and the motion to suspend the Rules was again rejected by yeas and nays 96 to 87. Wise said he should not offer it again— Peyton also reoffered his resolution; but the suspension of the rules was rejected byto

At one O’Clock the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, Hamer in the Chair, and Robertson in two hours and a quarter finished his Speech against the Administration; and was followed by Vanderpoel, on the other side about one hour, and then by Bellamy Storer, for 4 1/2 hours in a panegyrical biography of W. H. Harrison, in answer to Hawes on the Kentucky Resolutions— After 9 O’Clock, the motion to strike out the appropriation for the Navy yard at Portsmouth was rejected, and the Bill was at last reported to the House without amendment— It was close upon ten O’Clock when I got home— Dinnerless and sick—

div.p: 7. V:30. Thursday.

My wound continues to grow angry and my foot to swell— My hesitation to attend the house increased, but still my anxiety to discharge my duty still prevailed— Mr Frye was here and shewed me a Letter from Robert Buchanan, who is with the Army in Florida— At the House G. Grennell moved a suspension of the rules to enable him to offer a Resolution, instructing the Committee of Ways and Means, to report a Bill for distributing the proceeds of the Sales of public Lands, among the States, according to their population, with certain reservations for the States where the Lands lie—the suspension was refused by yeas and naysto. The Rules were suspended for an hour, and the House went into Committee of the whole Speight in the chair, on the Bill to establish the Territory of Wisconsin— Jones the territorial delegate and May of Illinois had agreed to introduce an amendment in the Bill recognizing the Northern Boundary of Illinois, “as fixed by Acts of Congress” instead of fixing it at Latitude 42’ 30.— Jones came to ask my assent to this, which I said I should not contest, considering it as agreed between the parties; but it was a surrender of the question The bill was taken up and the amendment passed without opposition; but a question was made upon a grant of Land to build a house for the Governor and Council of the Territory which after debate was turned into a grant of 20000 dollars: and the Bill was reported to the House and made the special order of the day to-morrow Morning— The Navy Appropriation Bill was then resumed and White of Florida moved again a large additional appropriation for the Navy-yard at Pensacola, which was carried by yeas and nays— The Bill passed to the third reading and passed 131 to 45. the united White and Harrison phalanx— The whole Massachusetts delegation voting for the appropriation— The House adjourned after six O’Clock on coming home I found the family at dinner— Mrs Frye and Thomas dined with us.
8. VIII. Friday—

The wound in my leg has been festering and inflaming for nearly three weeks— Eight or ten days neglected and disregarded— Then plaistered and poulticed; the ankle and foot swelling more and more every day, till I can scarcely crowd the foot into my slipper or shoe— Last night on going to bed I had a plaister of soap and sugar spread over the wound which worked like a hatchell of needles the whole Night and kept me without a wink of sleep— This morning, I could not touch the foot to the ground. The necessity became indispensable of laying myself up. Dr Huntt was here, and pronounced my leg a very bad one; ordering me to keep it without intermission in a horizontal and extended position—and prescribed an ointment plaster covered with a bread and milk poultice over the wound— I passed the whole day upon the Sopha, pining at the state of nullification to which I am reduced,—totally disqualified for application to business public or private— I wrote however a few lines to my Son Charles to give him notice of my condition, and that he may not be alarmed by learning my absence of the House from others— Towards Evening Mr John Gihon of New-York sent me a Letter from Gadsby’s, stating that he wished to communicate with the Committee of Manufactures on the question concerning the duties on brown Irish linens— I answered by referring him to Mr Gideon Lee, to whom I yesterday gave Mr Littlefield’s Letter and the sampler, telling him that it would probably not be in my power to attend the Meeting of the Committee or the House— I read three Chapters of Sir James Mackintosh’s History of the reign of James the second—and was deeply interested in the narrative of the trial of the seven Bishops, the hinge of the Revolution of 1688—
9. VI. Saturday.

Chained to my couch the whole day—with equivocal and sluggish symptoms of convalescence, but scarcely any of healing. Dr. Huntt now speaks of keeping me confined a week, which I understand as threatening a duration nearer to a month. I find myself disabled almost entirely from writing, and accomplished only the Journal of yesterday— I have still the inexpressible consolation of being able to read; and finished the part written by Sir James Mackintosh of the History of the Revolution of 1688— I read also one chapter of the continuation, by a very different had— By a man of different principles— Sir James writes as a whig—an ardent partizan of the Revolution, and almost worshipper of William the 3d.— The continuator is a revolutionary radical, affecting impartiality to the extent of discrediting William as much as James— Mackintosh deal’s too gently with William on his treatment of De Witt, and on the Battle of St. Denis.— He faintly questions the facts and somewhat sophistically extenuates the principles— The discussion upon the bribes received by patriots of England from Louis 14. is equally remarkable, as the prevarication of an honest mind, to palliate what it cannot justify— It is strange that James the second should have been dethroned and expelled as a tyrant, for measures the object of which was the establishment of religious toleration— Mackintosh’s hand in this work, as in his general History of England was arrested precisely at the period when it was acquiring the deepest interest— Mr W. S. Smith spent the Evening with us and we played two rubbers of whist— I read also two or three Chapters of Holland’s Life of Martin Van Buren—
10. VI. Sunday.

I was this day debarred from attendance upon Public worship, and fastened the whole day to my couch; with an increasing apprehension of being so confined for an indefinite further period— I answered one Letter from James C. Gilleland Editor of the Pittsburgh Times, and wrote some remarks in this Diary on Sir James Mackintosh’s portion of the History of the Revolution of 1688. which I read yesterday— I this day read several chapters of the continuation, which is far inferior as historical composition, and far less instructive in moral precept, and almost entirely destitute of profound philosophical reflection in which Mackintosh so richly abounds. The continuator writes more as a satyrist than as a historian, selecting for his narrative only incidents which give occasion to censorial remarks; and imputing to all the actors in the Scene none but selfish and sordid motives. If there is any one whom he treats with more tenderness than another it is James the second himself— Upon William the 3d. his queen Mary, the Princess Anne, her husband Prince George of Denmark, and all the Peerage, nobility Courtiers and Officers of the army and navy of the time he has no mercy— The expedition of William appears to have been rash even to foolhardiness— It is scarcely conceivable how it should have succeeded— There was nothing but treachery on all sides— I read also several chapters of the Life of Martin Van Buren, exhibiting the character of a modern politician— Dr Huntt brought the account of the taking by storm of Bexar by the Mexican General Santa Ana—and the disastrous fate of David Crockett— Dutee J. Pearce spent two hours of the Evening with me—
11. V:30 Monday.

Besides these personal visitors I had visits by Cards from Abbott Lawrence, Francis Granger. Caleb Cushing. A. Ward Gideon Hard and T. L. Smith Register of the Treasury— All but the last members of Congress— Dr Huntt daily visits me professionally, and daily protracts the period when I may expect to return to my public duties. With Mr Frye, I settled the account that I have had with Mr Thomas B. Johnson for a portion of the debt from the Columbian College which belonged to him; and which I paid principal and interest— Mr Johnson himself was here, and took leave of us. He is to embark at Baltimore for England— He goes to live somewhere— He knows not where— His object being to go any where, but where he is— Judge Cranch recommended to me Judkin’s Ointment for the ulcer in my leg, as a plaister which he has found useful in cases of similar wounds— Mr Lay has himself been confined to his chamber since last Thursday till this day; when he attended the house— Nothing was done there, but to receive Petitions; and the house adjourned upon a flurry raised by a Petition from Philadelphia presented by Slade, against admitting Arkansas as a State into the Union without a restriction upon Slavery— I continued reading the History of the Revolution of 1688. the success of which is a great historical phenomenon— The continuator appears to bear an unusual and unaccountable malice towards Bishop Burnet— This Revolution presents the first great conflict between the two principles of hereditary right and popular election that occurred in human history—and it is not a pleasant reflection that the issue depended perhaps entirely upon the false imputation of an imposture by James the second in imposing a supposititious child upon the world for his Son. I continued also the perusal of professor Hollands life of M Van Buren, but find it very dull
12. V:30. Tuesday

Mr Patterson was here this morning on the subject of his Petition to Congress for a Patent, for an invention for tanning hides; by his brother an inhabitant of Dublin in Ireland. I presented his petition which was referred to a select Committee of which Mr John Reed is Chairman— I spoke to him of this case and referred Patterson to him last week. He however mistook the name of Reed for Briggs, and now came and told me that Mr Briggs was gone home— I referred him again to Mr Reed, and gave him his name. Mr Jarvis came and spent an hour of the Evening with me. The House spent the two morning hours in motions to suspend the rules, to make special orders of the day; reconsiderations and previous questions— Taking the yeas and nays over and over again— They passed the Bill repealing the 14th. Section of the Act chartering the Bank of the United States and went into Committee of the whole upon the Bill making Appropriations for the civil and diplomatic expenses of Government, upon which he said Wise had opened a very animated debate— I finished reading the History of the Revolution of 1688, and the two Articles in the Appendix, in French, being James the 2ds. Narrative of his own absconding from England, and of the death-bed Scene of Charles the 2d. given by James to the Nuns of Chaillot— The grammatical discussions between the Lords and Commons upon the import of the words Abdication, Desertion and forfeiture, are amusing, and show upon what niceties of verbal criticism the greatest events in History depend— I made further progress also in professor Holland’s Life of Martin Van Buren; and see how the Snail has wound and is winding himself up to the top of the column, leaving the soft slime of democracy behind him to mark the track of his ascent— His talent consists in the accommodation of his principles to popular opinions—
13. V:45. Wednesday.

Steady and Heavy rain from morn till eve, when the weather cleared away— Mr William Brent came to speak of the application of his brother Daniel Brent, Consul of the United States at Paris, for additional compensation— He says Mr Forsyth, Secretary of State thinks it would be reasonable that the Consul at Paris should have the same allowances which have been authorised by Law, to Coll Aspinwall the Consul at London; but that Mr John Y. Mason, the Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations of the House of Representatives thinks that the Committee cannot be prevailed upon to recommend them— Mr Brent wishes me to move the allowance as an amendment in the general appropriation Bill now before the house; but this will require further consideration— Dr Huntt was here and by his direction the poultices on my leg are discontinued. It is apparently and very slowly healing— I still drag through the writing of my daily Diary, and wrote this day part of a Letter to Robert Walsh— Finished reading Holland’s Life of Martin van Buren, a partizan electioneering work written with much of that fraudulent democracy by the profession of which Thomas Jefferson rose to power in this Country, and of which he set the first successful example— Van Buren’s personal character bears however a stronger resemblance to that of Mr Madison than to Jefferson— They are both remarkable for their extreme caution in avoiding and averting personal collisions— Van Buren like the Sosie of Moliere’s Amphitryon is “l’ami de tout le monde”— This is perhaps the great secret of his success in public life, and especially against the competitors with whom he is now struggling, for the last step on the ladder of his ambition—Henry Clay and John C. Calhoun— They indeed are left upon the field for dead—and men of straw, Hugh L. White William H. Harrison and Daniel Webster, are thrust forward in their places— Neither of these has a principle to lean upon— Van Buren’s principle is the Talisman of Democracy, which so long as this union lasts can never fail.

div.p: 14. V:30. Thursday.

My leg was so much better this morning, that I obtained from Dr Huntt permission to go for a short time to the Capitol, and attend the House of Representatives— I went accordingly, soon after noon, and found the House, debating, on an amendment made in the House, to the Bill for establishing the Wisconsin territory, reducing the Salary of the Governor as fixed in the Senate’s Bill 2500 dollars as Governor and 1000 dollars as Superintendant of Indian Affairs— The amendment of the House had reduced the whole Salary to 2500 dollars— The Senate disagreement— The motion to recede was debating in the House, and B. Hardin was speaking against receding— The yeas and nays were soon after called and I voted for receding—but the House refused 131 to 55. It was past one O’Clock, and the order of the day, the general Appropriation Bill was taken up, in Committee of the whole on the Union, J. M. Patton in the Chair— Wise of Virginia moved successively to strike out two appropriations for contingencies in the Navy Commissioners Office, and in the Pension Office of the War Department— Each time making a Speech with heavy charges of wasteful and corrupt expenditures— In one of them he directly alluded to me and related what I had said to him a few days since in a private conversation— It made a sort of necessity for me to answer him, which I did in a very few words, but sufficient to prove to myself, my inability from weakness to address the house in any continuous discourse. Many of the members of all parties came and greeted me at my Seat—and among them the Speaker Polk— I left the House before 3. O’Clock and came home— Mr and Mrs Frye dined and spent the Evening with us. We made an Evening party at whist— The exercise and agitation of the day made my leg in the after part of it painful, and at night I found my ancle and foot again somewhat inflamed, and swollen— Mr T. B. Johnson left the City yesterday afternoon, and was to sail this day from Baltimore for England. I began reading the third volume of Sir James Mackintosh’s History of England—and Smollett’s reign of William and Mary—
15. V:15. Friday.

A man by the name of Josiah Morse, aged 73. a native of Preston, Connecticut, who lived many years in Worthington, Massachusetts, afterwards at Washington County, New-York, and last in Chautauque County of the same State, now in this City to solicit an appointment as keeper of a Light-House, brought me this morning his budget of Certificates and Recommendations, which I was compelled in civility to read— He wanted a written recommendation from me, but I gave him the name of the 5th. Auditor Stephen Pleasonton, who has charge of the Light-House Establishment and authorized him to say to Mr Pleasonton that I added my recommendation to the others— The man is a remarkable exemplification of the Yankee character— He has a pension of 8 dollars a month under the act of Congress of 1832 as a blacksmith in the Corps of Artificers— As the exercise of yesterday had the effect of swelling and inflaming my ancle and foot, Dr Huntt advised me not to go out this day, and I spent it almost entirely upon my Couch— I read in Sir James Mackintosh’s History of England a long chapter upon the affairs of Scotland— The melancholy tale of Queen Mary and David Rizzio, and Darnley and Bothwell, and the gunecocracy of Queen Elizabeth— Those of us who are conversant with the administration of Government in this Country can scarcely realize, the influence of personal interests and passions, upon public affairs;—especially in female monarchies— The history of Scotland in Mary’s time is only the account of her amours and marriages, with the murder of one lover by a husband, and the murder of the husband by another Lover.— The character of Mary has been treated by all the historians with a degree of tenderness which I cannot readily extend to her— She was no doubt beautiful, and susceptible of warm affections, but the precipitation and desperation of her can be palliated only by passing it to the account of weakness in the Understanding— I read also a small portion of Smolletts History of William and Mary, and finished a Letter to Robert Walsh— The day was gone, before I had time to reflect how it was going.
16. V:15. Saturday.

After Dr Huntt had made his visit I concluded with his permission to go to the House, which I found in Session, in Committee of the whole, Hawes in the Chair, debating a Bill in addition to the Revolutionary Pension Laws; which was reported to the House and passed to a third reading— Just before the order of the day was called, I obtained leave to present two petitions from Inhabitants of Nantucket for a Breakwater—old Petitions taken from the files, and referred to the Committee of Commerce— Other Petitions to the same effect had already been referred to the Committee on the motion of John Reed— The Petition of 2673 Ladies of Massachusetts, went of course to the Select Committee on the abolition Petitions; and the Petition of Edward D. Tippett concerning his invention of an unexplodable Steam-Engine, was referred to the Select Committee on certain Patents— These Petitions should have been presented last Monday, when I was detained by my lameness from attendance at the House

At one O’Clock the general Appropriation Bill was taken up, as reported yesterday by the Committee of the whole on the Union to the House— Several amendments reported by the Committee were adopted without debate— An Appropriation of 20000 dollars, in the Bill reported by the Committee of Ways and Means, towards fulfilment of a contract with Matthew St. Clair Clarke and Peter Force, for publishing a Documentary History of the Revolution, authorized by Act of Congress of 2. March 1833—was struck out in Committee of the whole; and the question of concurring with the Committee was warmly debated— I made a short, but very feeble Speech in favour of fulfilling the contract, with humbling conviction of my debility— About 4. O’Clock the House adjourned without taking the Question Mr John Connell spent an hour of the Evening with me— Recommends Swaim’s Panacea—
17. V:15. Sunday

I had earnestly hoped and purposed to attend on public worship both parts of this day; but the weather was dull and gloomy, with a North east wind, and rain, and I was dissuaded both by my wife and by Dr Huntt from going out— I confined myself to the house, and meditated upon the decays of my own faculties of body and mind; too clearly demonstrated by daily accumulating proof to leave me even the comfort of self-delusion— Dr Huntt proposes to open an issue in my arm as an outlet to those humours which are breaking out with increasing virulence; and one of which has now crippled me for nearly three weeks— But an issue once opened could never again be closed without fatal consequences and I have not yet brought my mind to so desperate a remedy— The Doctor however gave me a fair warning of my danger in postponing it. I occupied myself as well as I could with the drudgery of assorting papers and addressing Documents; and alternately keeping up the current of this dull diary, and reading in Sir James Mackintosh’s History of the reign of the reign of Elizabeth— This third Volume seems to be in a style less carefully revised than the other works of the author, but it has the peculiar interest of relating the origin and early progress of the Puritans— I took again a cursory glance at Dr Lingard’s Popish History of England eminently contrasting with the liberal Spirit of Mackintosh. Lingard without absolutely pronouncing Anne Boleyn guilty of the crimes for which she suffered leaves scarcely a doubt that she was so, and faintly censuring the bloody persecutions of Mary extols her as a virtuous and amiable character.
18. V:15. Monday

Waking before daylight and waiting for the dawn, I composed a Sonnet before I rose, having written six lines of comment last Evening upon the motto—Fidem Libertatem Amicitiam for an autograph— This morning I attended at 10 O’Clock the meeting of the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Judson, Lee and Webster Absent M’Comas— Two drafts of Sections for a Bill to release them from duties prepared by Mr David S. Lyons, deputy collector at New-York, were considered and postponed till Thursday to which day the meeting was adjourned— The Bill from the Senate was also postponed till that time— Afterwards in the House, Mr Gideon Lee brought me a Letter from Mr D. S. Lyons, who wished another interview with the Committee; and as he must leave the City to-morrow afternoon I agreed to call a meeting of the Committee to-morrow morning, and sent round the notices accordingly— At the House It was petition day; but there were unfinished questions which would have absorbed the day. John Reed moved to suspend the rules till one O’Clock, to receive Petitions to which there would be no objection, and Post-Office Resolutions—this was agreed to— The States were called beginning with Maine—the Speaker proceeded to Massachusetts when I presented the Petition from 2673 Ladies of Massachusetts for the abolition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, which went of course to the select Committee; and a petition from Wareham to be set off as a separate collection District from New-Bedford which was referred to the Committee of Commerce— These were admitted without objection— But immediately after Wise objected to every Petition presented, till the vote of the House was reconsidered and the rule was suspended for the reception of Petitions without restriction— Then came up the snarl upon the Petition presented by Slade against Slavery in Arkansas, upon which Wise and he descanted till one O’Clock when the order of the day, the general Appropriation Bill was called— The Committee of the whole had struck out 20000 dollars for Clarke and Force’s Documentary History of the Revolution— It was debated till past 5, and the Appropriation restored 93 to 85— I spoke twice in favour of it— Persico was here this Evening— His models are finished.

div.p: 19. V:15. Tuesday

Dr. Huntt was here this morning, and inspected my leg; which is better, but not yet well— I attended the Committee of manufactures— Present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Holsey, Judson and Lee— Absent Granger, M’Comas and Webster Mr David S. Lyons, and Mr Barker the Collector of Philadelphia conferred with the Committee— Mr Lyons’s draughts of Sections were returned to him to be revised—it was agreed to propose a Section respecting blankets as an amendment to the Senate’s Bill—and a Section respecting iron was also discussed— Adjourned to Thursday Morning— Found the House in Session— I presented by leave of the House a Petition from sundry Citizens of Michigan, remonstrating against the Bill reported for the admission of that State into the Union, on the conditions reported by the judiciary Committee— It was ordered at my Motion to be printed and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union which have the Bill before them— Dromgoole called up his Resolution of enquiries, of the dealings between the Treasury Department, and the deposit Banks, and Wise made a Speech in support of his proposed amendment—which was also sustained by Balie Peyton— The hour of one came—but Dromgoole was suffered to reply—in support of his resolution, which he did briefly and feebly. W. B. Calhoun took the floor but the order of the day was called, and the general appropriation Bill taken up— The Committee of the whole on the Union had reported an Amendment of 200000 dollars for the custom house at Boston— Underwood proposed as an Amendment a proviso, that the house should cost no more than that sum, but afterwards modified the limitation to 350000, this gave rise to a warm debate. Abbott Lawrence made two handsome Speeches in favour of the appropriation— I said a few words in favour of it—which brought up C. F. Mercer twice in favour of the limitation, and a hot debate till past 4. Underwood’s limitation was rejected by yeas and nays 88 to 82 and the Appropriation adopted without a division— An Amendment proposed by Cave Johnson then followed; but he was not in the house, and upon a second motion to adjourn it prevailed. Eve writing—

div.p: 20. V:30. Wednesday.

Call at the Bank of the Metropolis and thence proceeded to the House. After the reading of the Journal, Wise with leave of the House, made a statement, denying the representation made in the Globe of one or two of his Speeches, yesterday, or the day before—after which Reports from the standing Committees were called— Then the Bill from the Senate fixing the Northern boundary of the State of Ohio, and providing for the admission of the State of Michigan into the Union, was taken up and Thomas proposed should be discussed without referring to the Committee of the whole on the Union; which gave rise to a warm debate which continued till one O’Clock when the order of the day was called—the general Appropriation Bill— Cave Johnson had proposed an additional Section requiring annual Statements and accounts of the contingent expenditures of each of the Executive Departments and by the Secretary of the Senate and Clerk of the House to be made to the Congress— Augustin Sheppard offered an amendment to the Amendment, to include the Accounts of the expenditures of the contingent expenses of foreign intercourse—this made another very heated debate upon the amendment to the amendment, and upon the amendment itself— I spoke against them both— The former was modified at the motion of M’Kay to obviate my objection—and the latter was carried by yeas and nays 131 to 56— The previous question upon the engrossment of the Bill was then moved and seconded 95 to 74—and the vote for putting the main question was 104 to 70— The bill passed to a third reading without a division— I took Jarvis home; and found myself so much exhausted in the Evening that I had scarcely strength either to read or write— Invitation to my wife and me to a party this Evening at Mrs Butler’s the Lady of the Attorney General; which we declined because of indisposition—
21. V:30. Thursday.

Dr Huntt was sent for, and came and inspected and new dressed the wound upon my leg, which is troublesome and vexatious— I attended the Committee of Manufactures—Present Adams, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Lee, Judson and Webster,—absent Denny and M’Comas. The written communications left by Mr David S. Lyon, were read considered and debated till the House was in Session, when the Committee adjourned to Saturday Morning a question was taken whether any modification of the duties upon the brown-tincted linens, should be proposed. Lee, Holsey and Webster voted for it—Granger, Judson and Dickerson against it, and with them I voted, in favour of the manufacturing interest— In the House Sundry resolutions were offered, and some adopted— Hawes moved the suspension of the Rules to fix a day for considering his Resolution for the appointment of a Committee for enquiring into the expediency of re-organizing the West-Point Academy—the vote was 106 to 69 for suspending the rules—not quite two thirds— A Bill was then taken up, which had been made the order of this day from 12 to 1. to raise an additional regiment of Dragoons, and to accept the services of Volunteers, reported by the Military Committee, which sprung a debate which at one O’Clock, was arrested and the Chairman of the Committee of the whole, Muhlenberg left the Chair of course and the Speaker resumed it— The General Appropriation Bill was read the third time, when Mercer moved to recommit the Bill to the Committee of the whole on the Union with Instructions to restrict the appropriation for the Custom House at New-York to 100000 dollars; and an additional Section to distribute 23 millions of dollars proceeds of the public Lands, among the people of the several States, according to their respective federal population— Mercer supported his motion by a vehement Speech and was answered by French of Kentucky— Speight moved the previous question, which was carried. The Speaker decided that the main question was the passage of the Bill.— Mercer appealed and withdrew his appeal— Bill past— Adjourned
22. V:30. Friday

Last evening Mr Drane called upon me, as the Agent of many persons in three Counties of the State of Ohio, to remonstrate against a projected alteration of the Cumberland Road, from the course already fixed, to go by the way of Dayton— This Morning in the House, Mr Waddy Thompson of South-Carolina, gave me 8 Copies of Chancellor William Harper’s Oration to the South-Carolina Society for the advancement of Learning. This sitting was a very quiet one— Several reports from standing Committees were received— The Bill authorising the President to accept the services of Volunteers, was taken up in Committee of the whole on the Union, Muhlenberg in the chair, and an Amendment moved by M’Kay was debated till One O’Clock, when the Committee rose, under the limitation of time in the special order of the House. It was a day for private business; but the rules were suspended to go immediately into Committee of the whole, and resume the Bill authorizing the President to accept the services of Volunteers— Ashley of Missouri moved an Additional Section, to authorize the raising of a second Regiment of Dragoons, upon which a debate followed, in which I took a part— I objected to the insertion of Ashley’s Amendment as incongruous and inconsistent with the Bill itself. The amendment was however carried. I proposed two amendments which were adopted; one to limit the amount of the Appropriation to 300000 dollars—and the other a proviso to exempt from the limitation of time to the bill, the rights and privileges secured by it to the volunteers— Upon the specification of the sum to be appropriated M’Kay opposed my amendment and quoted the Law-maxim Id certum est quod certum reddi potest—to which I replied— The Bill was reported to the House. Adjourned at 1/2 past five, and I waited till five to go home I took Jarvis home—
23. V:30. Saturday.

Dr. Huntt called this morning; but without inspecting my leg advised me to prudence in using it— My Catarrhal cough is still troublesome— The children went with me to the capitol— Attended the Meeting of the Committee of Manufactures, present Adams, Granger, Lee, Holsey absent Denny Dickerson, Judson, Webster. It was so late that except reading a Letter from Peter H Schenk to Mr Judson, nothing was done. Adjourned to 1/2 past 9. Tuesday Morning— In the House, Dromgoole moved to suspend the Rules to take up till one O Clock his Resolution calling on the Secretary of the Treasury, for certain information, concerning the deposit Banks—with Wise amendment proposing the appointment of a select Committee for the same purpose— The rules were suspended— There was some question between W. B. Calhoun and Gillett Calhoun obtained the floor; moved an Amendment to Wise’s Amendments enlarging the enquiry, and supported his motion by a Speech of about an hour—his almost maiden Speech— Wise accepted the Amendment, and modified his own— Bond of Ohio began a Speech upon the whole subject, till one O’Clock when the order of the day was called for private business— Committee of the whole, Thompson of Ohio in the Chair, and Sutherland as Speaker, several private Bills were considered, some postponed and others reported to the House; till past five O’Clock, when the Committee rose, and the House, with very little business completed adjourned— I took Jarvis home— Mr Bond of Ohio asked me for a copy of my suppressed Speech on the removal of the Deposites, which I promised to send him— Thomas J. Frye dined with us— I spoke this morning to Mr Granger of a petition to Congress, directed jointly to him W. Slade and me, which I agreed to present.
24. V:45 Sunday.

My grand-child, Mary-Louisa was taken suddenly ill, and fainted while she was reading to me the 12th. Chapter of Nehemiah, but soon recovered. I walked to the Presbyterian Church and heard Mr. Butts, from Numbers 14.21. “But as truly as I live, all the earth shall be filled with the glory of the Lord.” He said that all the earth here meant a very small part of the Earth— That of the whole population of the globe there were six hundred millions sunk in the depths of heathen ignorance and superstition— One hundred and twenty Millions of Mohammedans very little elevated above the barbarous pagans— That of one hundred and sixty-five Millions of nominal Christians, one hundred and ten Millions were roman catholics, slaves and dupes to the imposture of Popery; and that of the fifty five Millions of Protestants, not more than five Millions were orthodox believers; and that of those five Millions the proportion of true converted children of God, the number was fearfully small. And yet that very small number were all by whom the glory of the Lord could be said to fill the whole Earth— From his division of Christians into Roman Catholics and Protestants he seemed not to know the existence of a Greek Church— There were other incongruities in the discourse— After Church meeting and walking home in company with Mrs Macomb, she told me she expected the General back in a few days— Morning visit from P. R. Fendall. Mr and Mrs Frye and Thomas dined with us— I wrote to Dr Waterhouse, and read Chancellor Harper’s Oration— I wrote also these Lines
[symbols]
25. V:30. Monday.

Call at the office of the commanding general, and left a Letter for Lieutt. T. B. Adams, to be forwarded; and then at the Navy Department— I gave the Secretary Dickerson, the Letter of Captain Nicholson, recommending J. Q. Adams second, for his Midshipman’s warrant, which the Secretary promised to send me— I requested also that the name of James Theodore Talbot 11. years old should be entered on the list of applicants for a Midshipman’s warrant—the Secretary thought as I did that his chance of success would be fairest by entering him as of Kentucky where his father resides and belongs, rather than of the District of Columbia, where he himself lives with his mother— His name was entered with my recommendation— At the House— The appeal from the Speaker’s decision that the Petition for the interdiction of Slavery in Arkansas presented by Slade, was referred to H. L. Pinckney’s committee was at the motion of Speight laid on the table by yeas and nays—The Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky, in favour of the distributor of the proceeds of the public Lands among the States, were resumed and Hawes with permission of the House replied to Storer’s panegyric upon William H. Harrison, pronounced in Committee of the whole— Hawes concluded about half past 12. and Sherrod Williams took the floor but moved to postpone the subject till next Monday— This was agreed to, and the half hour till 1. was consumed in receiving Petitions and Resolutions presented by individual members— I presented Resolutions of the Legislature of Massachusetts in favour of Clay’s Land Bill, and of Appropriations for fortifications in Boston Harbour, which were read and ordered to be printed and laid on the table. At one— Order of the day. Committee of the whole on the Union. Sutherland in the Chair Bill for one million additional appropriation to suppress the Indian hostilities in Florida—Bill for Indian Treaty Appropriation, Bill of Appropriations for additional Clerks; all reported to the House; adjourned at 4. O’Clock— Mary went to Mrs W. S. Smith’s
26. V:45. Tuesday

My leg became again painful last night, and threatens to be long troublesome— Yet the children rode this morning with me to the Capitol— At 1/2 past 9 I attended the Committee of manufactures— Present Adams, Dickerson, Holsey, Lee, M’Comas and Webster—absent, Denny, Granger and Judson— Took up the Bill from the Senate N. 99. and agreed to propose amendments striking out sundry articles on which the Bill proposes to repeal or reduce—one Article additional of Amendment was agreed on—one referred to the chairman to revise, and one postponed for further consideration—to Thursday morning— At the House Glascock moved to suspend the rule to offer to be read a Declaration from some members of a corporate body at Bristol Pennsylvania, that they never signed a memorial against Slavery in Arkansas— I moved as an amendment that the memorial itself should also be read; which Glascock accepted, but the whole subject at the motion of Sevier, the Delegate from Arkansas, was laid on the Table— The Resolutions of the Legislature of Kentucky, for the distribution of the proceeds of the public Lands, came up, and Bond of Ohio continued his speech till One O’Clock, and the orders of the day was called. Waddy Thompson asked the consent of the House to offer a Resolution, calling on the President for information respecting the recent massacre in Texas; but his motion was rejected— The Bills for Indian Treaty and additional Clerk Appropriations were read the third time and passed— The volunteer anddragoon second regiment Bill was taken up and the Amendments reported by the Committee of the whole, were warmly debated— But Mr Clay was speaking on his Land-Bill in the Senate, and no Quorum in the House There were two calls of the House, and yeas and nays upon a question of adjournment before 3. O’Clock— The Bill finally passed— The yeas and nays were taken on the seventh Section, for raising an additional Regiment of Dragoons and it was carried 144 to 32
Adjourned about 4 O’Clock, and I came home sick and dejected I could only read in the Evening.
27. V:30. Wednesday

Dr Huntt came this morning, and examined and dressed my suffering limb, which has been very painful and distressing— I called at Brown’s Hotel, and then at Mrs Peyton’s, where I saw Mrs and Miss Gilman, wife and daughter of the Revd. Samuel Gilman of Charleston S.C—they had left at my house a Letter from him introducing them to me— At the House I saw Mr and Mrs Edward Cruft who came from Baltimore yesterday, and are going to return there to night— At the house Waddy Thompson renewed his motion to suspend the rules to enable him to offer a Resolution calling upon the President for information, concerning the condition of the War raging in Texas— The motion was rejected by yeas and nays— The Bill for authorizing the President to accept the services of Volunteers and for raising an additional Regiment of Dragoons or of mounted riflemen. Mann of New-York moved an useless amendment, at the third reading to which I objected— The Bill was passed— There was a struggle to suspend the rules for a Resolution to fix the first Wednesday in May to consider specially the Bill for settling the Northern boundary of Ohio, and the two Bills for the admission of the States of Michigan and Arkansas—but the motion failed by yeas and nays— The order of the day then came up, the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, John Y. Mason in the chair; and the Army Appropriation Bill N. 55. was taken up— The Bill proposed 200000 dollars for arming the fortifications— Cambreleng moved to increase the item to 1204and made a Speech of an hour and a half in reply to Bell of Tennessee’s Speech on the Navy Appropriation Bill— Bell retaliated by a Speech of an hour; followed by C. F. Mercer—the Committee rose without coming to any result and the house adjourned— I was called out to Mr Robert Rantoul junr. a member of the Legislature of Massachusetts— Mrs W S. Smith dined with us, and Mary returned home from her visit to her— Mr Smith himself returned this Evening from New-York—
28. V:30 Thursday.

Met the Committee of Manufactures—present Adams, Denny, Dickerson, Granger, Holsey, Lee, M’Comas, and Webster—absent Judson— The remaining amendments proposed by D. S. Lyon were considered and decided.— Holsey of Georgia moved an additional Section, repealing all duties of and under 20 per, cent ad valorem—which was rejected Mr Lee moved the repeal of the duty upon coal, rejected— The Chairman was directed to prepare the amendments agreed to in the Committee, and they adjourned to Tuesday Morning. In the House the Rules of the House were suspended till one O’Clock, to consider Dromgoole’s resolution of enquiry with the amendment of Wise—and Bond of Ohio concluded his speech at half-past twelve— He was followed by Franklin Pierce, who confined himself to a defence of the Secretary of the Treasury, Woodbury— At one, the order of the day was called, but Pierce promised to finish his Speech within ten minutes, and was allowed to conclude— Gillett of New-York then took the floor; but the House resolved to pass to the order of the day. In Committee of the whole on the Union, J. Y. Mason in the chair, Ely Moore of the City of New-York, who had taken the floor yesterday, commenced a Speech upon Aristocracy, Democracy, the working man, Agrarianism, and the History of the world— After declaiming with some elegance of language and great violence of manner, he fainted, and was taken out of the Hall— A motion was made that the Committee should rise, but Whittlesey proposed to continue the discussion, and when Mr Moore should recover and return to the House he should be entitled to resume the floor—then Mercer’s amendment was again brought up, and after a short Speech from him, M’Keon of New-York, expatiated at large, upon the merits of the present administration— After him M’Comas took the floor, but it was near five O’Clock—the Committee rose, and the house adjourned— My wife spent the Evening at her Sister Frye’s and Mary at her friends the Misses Cottringer— I was left alone and read Ford’s Comedy of the Lover’s Melancholy— Very dull—
29. V:30. Friday

Mr W. B. Hodgson called upon me this morning: as Mr Peyton Gay late Consul of the United States at the island of Teneriffe called me out from my Seat in the Hall, yesterday— Hodgson went out two years since as Dragoman at Constantinople; but could not agree with Commodore Porter who is the Chargé d’Affaires to the sublime Porte, and is now Consul perhaps at Morocco— He says the renewal of the Treaty with Morocco is in the process of Negotiation— On my way to the Capitol I stopped at the Bank of the Metropolis, and took a draft on the Manhattan Company, to be endorsed payable to A. B. Durand— At the House the first hour was wasted in trifling—repeated motions to suspend the rules— By Sherrod Williams, for him to offer a Resolution of enquiry into the expediency of acknowledging the Independence of Texas— By Hawes to offer his Resolution for the abolition or re-organization of the West-Point Academy By Rencher for a Resolution to Water the Pennsylvania Avenue— The last prevailed and was debated chiefly between Hawes and Lane till the order of the day was called; for private business— Two or three Bills were called up contested and postponed— A message from the President was read with a present of a Catalogue of a Library from England. Motions to adjourn were made and repeated till shortly after two O’Clock, when one succeeded— I went to the Chamber of the Committee of Manufactures, and prepared a report of Amendments to the Bill from the Senate N. 99—for reducing the duties of impost on some Articles, and otherwise amending the Tariff Laws— I reviewed and assorted the Papers of the Committee, and thought of proposing to the Committee to prepare a further report—besides that on the Bill from the Senate— At 5 I came home, but left my Chronometer at Montandon’s— Mary went with Mrs Frye, to spend the Evening with Mrs Barrell
30. V:30. Saturday

The House adjourned over from yesterday till Tuesday, to ventilate the Hall, and put it in summer dress, and to afford the members an opportunity for an excursion to Harper’s ferry, by invitation from the President and Directors of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal— Doctor Huntt thought it would be most prudent for me to rest and nurse my leg and foot at home and I do accordingly. Mr Nye of Wareham called upon me to recommend the petition from that place to be set off as a separate collection district from New-Bedford which I promised to look to— Dr Huntt was here, but thought it not necessary to dress my leg before Monday— I called at the bounty land Office, and left the Letter of enquiry from Mr Lucas of Plymouth concerning Josiah Cotton— At the Navy Department, and left with Mr Boyle the chief Clerk a Letter to my nephew and namesake, enclosing his Midshipman’s warrant to be forwarded to him in the Mediterranean Squadron. Mr Polk the Speaker came in while I was there— Mr Boyle spoke to me about purchasing the Columbian Mills— Mrs Alexander had done so on Thursday; but neither of them has the means— At the General Land Office, I left with the Commissioner Ethan Allen Brown a Letter from Corey of enquiry— The rest of the day, at home, reading and writing— My wife and Mary rode out after dinner.
Our Country.

lg.l: My Country—what then is there in the name
What is the charm that binds me unto thee?
Tis not that thou art fair, that thou art free
That thou art foremost in the field of Fame
Throughout Earth’s regions, thou art still the same;
Equator, Tropics, Poles, whereer ye be
Alike unmov’d the Patriots eye can see
The blaze of glory, and the blush of shame.
Such is the voice of Nature and of God
Wherever first our infant footsteps trod
There is the Country of our earliest love—
Not so the Christian— He is not of Earth
Throughout the Universe he seeks his birth
And finds his Country, in the realms above.

div.p: Lines written in answer to a Letter from Geo. W. Niles Hanover New Hampshire requesting my signature and a Sentiment in honour of our Common Country—

lg.l: The man tenacious of his trust,
True to his purpose, firm and just
With equal scorn defies
The rabble’s rage, the tyrant’s frown
And martyrdom’s unfading crown
Awaits him in the skies.
Should all the elements conspire
With inextinguishable fire
To wrap this earthly ball
To atoms crushing every rock,
Undaunted he would meet the shock
And spotless fearless fall—
